channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Saturday Profile: President-Elect Stirs Optimism in Iran and West
item.description: Hassan Rouhani is concerned about his country’s growing economic troubles and is determined to change policies that have cut off relations with most of the developed world.
item.dc:creator: By THOMAS ERDBRINK
item.media:credit: Newsha Tavakolian for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hassan Rouhani, Iran’s incoming president, negotiated the only nuclear deal between Iran and the West in the last 11 years, and he seems determined ease the harsh tactics of his predecessor.

item.title: A Trail of Masterpieces and a Web of Lies, Leading to Anguish
item.description: Investigators are nowhere closer to learning the fate of seven paintings, including works by Picasso, Matisse and Monet, that were stolen by a Romanian criminal gang from a Dutch museum.
item.dc:creator: By ANDREW HIGGINS
item.media:description: Radu Dogaru, in a video image. He says he stole famous artworks in Rotterdam. His mother has said she burned them.

item.title: Egypt Military Flexes Muscle Against Morsi Amid Rallies
item.description: After announcing that Mohamed Morsi could face serious criminal charges, the Egyptian military orchestrated a display of military power in an effort to crack down on demonstrators.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT F. WORTH and KAREEM FAHIM
item.media:credit: Narciso Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: A helicopter flew over the protests in Tahrir Square.

item.title: Soldiers’ Mass Execution Reported by Syria Group
item.description: Extremists in Syria’s insurgency killed 150 government fighters, including 51 who were executed after they had surrendered, a monitoring group said.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By HANIA MOURTADA and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Tunisia Says Assassination Has Links to Al Qaeda
item.description: Already criticized for failing to find those responsible for the February killing of another opposition figure, the government was under pressure to produce some answers.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL
item.media:credit: Gianni Cipriano for The New York Times
item.media:description: Antigovernment demonstrators in front of the National Constituent Assembly in Friday in Tunis, a day after the killing of a leader of the opposition.

item.title: G.M. Dismisses Executives After India Begins Investigating Recall of Vehicles
item.description: An inquiry started this week into the recall this week of 114,000 Chevrolet Tavera utility vehicles.
item.category: Chevrolet Division of General Motors Corp
item.dc:creator: By BILL VLASIC
item.media:description: Sam Winegarden, a vice president, retired this week after 44 years with G.M., which said he had violated company policies.

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Greece: Shipping Magnate Jailed Pending Money Laundering Trial
item.description: A Greek shipping fleet owner, Victor Restis, has been imprisoned pending trial on money laundering and embezzlement charges, court officials said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Pakistan: Twin Bombings Underscore Sectarian Tensions in Tribal Region
item.description: In a deadly sectarian attack, at least 45 people were killed Friday evening and about 75 wounded when two bombs ripped through a town in a tribal region of northwestern Pakistan.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Switzerland: Armed Men Help ‘Pink Panther’ Member Escape
item.description: The gang member escaped with another prisoner after accomplices in two vehicles forced their way through a gate and fired at prison guards.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Africa: Zimbabwe: Prime Minister Criticizes Preparations for National Elections
item.description: Zimbabwe’s prime minister, Morgan Tsvangirai, said Friday that he was deeply disturbed by chaotic preparations for the nation’s elections next Wednesday.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: Wild Swings in Markets Fuel Anxiety of Japanese
item.description: After many years of doldrums, the economy in Japan appears to be re-energized and novices are testing the market waters. But volatility may stifle their enthusiasm.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI
item.media:description: An electronic board of a securities firm in Tokyo. After an 80 percent ascent over six months, the Nikkei 225 stock index turned sharply downward in mid-May.

item.title: Delay in Disclosing Leaks at Fukushima Is Criticized
item.description: The lack of transparency by the operator, Tokyo Electric Power Company, in revealing that contaminated water from the site had been flowing into the ocean has renewed public frustration.
item.dc:creator: By HIROKO TABUCHI

item.title: The Lede: Tahrir Taken, Some Egyptians Look for ‘Third Square’ to Resist Islamists and Army
item.description: On a day of mass rallies by supporters of Egypt’s army and the rival Muslim Brotherhood, some activists were left wondering how best to register their disgust with both the military and the Islamists.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Supreme Council of the Armed Forces (Egypt)
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: 45 Killed in Sectarian Bombings in Pakistan
item.description: A militant group affiliated with the Pakistani Taliban claimed responsibility for the deaths in Parachinar, the main town in a tribal region near the Afghan border.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: France Orders Strauss-Kahn to Stand Trial
item.description: French magistrates charged Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former chief of the International Monetary Fund, and 12 others with “aggravated procurement in a group,” or pimping.
item.dc:creator: By SCOTT SAYARE

item.title: U.S. to Send 2 at Guantánamo Back to Algeria, Saying Security Concerns Are Met
item.description: The White House’s announcement comes as William K. Lietzau, the top Pentagon official dealing with detainees, is stepping down to take a private sector job.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Black Boxes Found and Driver Arrested in Spanish Train Crash
item.description: Francisco José Garzón Amo was arrested as investigators examined records from the train’s “black box” to determine the cause of the crash, which killed 78 people.
item.dc:creator: By SILVIA TAULÉS and DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Xoan Soler/La Voz de Galicia, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: The train driver, Francisco José Garzón Amo, was helped by two men after the accident on Wednesday.

item.title: Lens Blog: Ode to a Polish River
item.description: Mikolaj Nowacki grew up along the river Odra in Poland, taking in its sounds and its smells. Years later, he returned with his camera to what he calls the “river of history.”
item.dc:creator: By MATT MCCANN

item.title: U.S. Letter Says Leaker Won’t Face Death Penalty
item.description: In a letter to the Russian minister of justice, Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. said the United States was also willing to issue a passport to Edward J. Snowden so he could return to the country.
item.dc:creator: By MICHAEL S. SCHMIDT and STEVEN LEE MYERS

item.title: World Briefing | Europe: Bribery Charges Withdrawn in Czech Corruption Case
item.description: The prosecutor annulled charges against three former members of Parliament after the Supreme Court ruled they were protected by parliamentary immunity.
item.dc:creator: By DAN BILEFSKY

item.title: Bombings at Busy Market in Pakistan Kill Dozens
item.description: A pair of bombs tore through crowds of shoppers at a busy market in Parachinar in northern Pakistan on Friday, killing at least 39 people, officials said.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: On Religion: A Jewish Pathbreaker Inspired by Her Countryman Mandela
item.description: Sara Hurwitz was informed by her childhood in South Africa in her quest for an Orthodox ordination.
item.dc:creator: By SAMUEL G. FREEDMAN
item.media:credit: Angela Jimenez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sara Hurwitz, the dean of Yeshivat Maharat, right, congratulates inaugural graduates Ruth Balinsky, left, and Rachel Kohl Finegold at a ceremony in June.

item.title: U.S. Assures Russia Snowden Won't Be Tortured or Executed
item.description: The U.S. Attorney General Eric H. Holder Jr. wrote in a letter to his Russian counterpart this week that Edward J. Snowden would have all the protections of the U.S. civilian court system if he were sent home.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: French Prosecutors Plan to Charge Strauss-Kahn With Pimping
item.description: Dominique Strauss-Kahn, the former head of the International Monetary Fund, will be tried on charges of pimping, French prosecutors in Lille said on Friday.
item.dc:creator: By REUTERS

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: July 26
item.description: Tribute was paid to martyrs of the 1999 Kargil war fought with Pakistan, at the India Gate memorial in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: On the 14th anniversary of the Kargil war, defense personnel congregated at India Gate in New Delhi to pay tribute to the martyrs. It was the last war fought between India and Pakistan.
